25730003.trustfund:
BBRSB-BB RESEARCH SUPPORT BUDGET,TF021456-DUTCH/EDI COLLABORATIVE PROGRAM
            - EDIHR,TF036124-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF037823-ECA REGION - HEALTH,TF039120-UZBEKISTAN HEALTH PROJECT,TF038774-ARMENIA - SUPERVISION OF
            PRIMARY HEALTH CARE PROJECTS,TF039773-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF033632-UZBEKISTAN - AGRICULTURE,TF034308-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH 1 PROJECT,TF034711-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH I PROJECT,TF035016-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH 1 PROJECT,TF035495-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH 1,TF022689-PHRD-HEALTH CARE REFORM PROJECT,TF020889-SOCIAL SCIENTISTS NETWORK IN
            CENTRAL ASIA

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Health Project of Uzbekistan
            had the following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both satisfactory. Lessons learned: pilot projects are
            necessary and useful to test new ways of doing business. In
            the current government set-up, line ministries have a very
            limited role in decision making. The Government re-directed
            some of the savings from rationalization into emergency care
            instead of using the opportunity to address the overcapacity
            and duplication in the system of secondary and tertiary
            care. Further improvements need to be made in coordinating
            different government organizations involved in health care
            and support service delivery. Lack of back of baseline data
            at the beginning of the project impacted unfavorably on
            monitoring capacities. More emphasis should also be given to
            long-term sustainability of investments in project
            management staff, and to integrating this staff as much as
            possible and as soon as feasible into the ministries and/or
            their regular, permanent implementation agencies. Computer
            centers at the rayon level basically conduct census tasks
            that would be better managed by the rayon administration in
            line with general statistics and government information needs.

TF039773-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF021456-DUTCH/EDI COLLABORATIVE PROGRAM
            - EDIHR,TF030571-IDA CONSULTANTS POOLED CTF - FY04,TF033632-UZBEKISTAN - AGRICULTURE,TF034711-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH I PROJECT,TF020889-SOCIAL SCIENTISTS NETWORK IN
            CENTRAL ASIA,TF036124-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF034308-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH 1 PROJECT,TF030452-ITALIAN CTF (EE) FY04 - ECA
            (ALBANIA, AZERBAIJAN, BOSNIA-HERZEGOVINA, B,TF030622-IDA CONSULTANTS POOLED CTF - FY05,TF038774-ARMENIA - SUPERVISION OF
            PRIMARY HEALTH CARE PROJECTS,TF022689-PHRD-HEALTH CARE REFORM PROJECT,TF039120-UZBEKISTAN HEALTH PROJECT,TF035016-UZBEKISTAN - HEALTH 1 PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Project for Uzbekistan at the
            oblast level aims to 1) improve the quality and cost
            effectiveness of primary health care, particularly in rural
            areas; 2) develop a new cadre of medical personnel; and 3)
            fully strengthen the management and financing of primary
            health care services, in part through incentive
            restructuring and decentralization in both financing and
            providing health care. At the national level the project
            builds the capacity of the health ministry to evaluate and
            disseminate results of the pilot countrywide. There are four
            components including project management. The other three
            components 1) strengthen primary health care services by
            providing basic diagnostic, therapeutic, and laboratory
            equipment, furnishings, medical supplies and laboratory
            reagents, vehicles, and a packet radio communication system
            in selected locales, along with equipment, training, and
            foreign and local technical assistance; 2) develop a faculty
            department in a medical institute, and training programs for
            trainers, practicing physicians, and nurses as well as
            reform medical education while introducing a new
            accreditation process for medical training institutions and
            the certification and licensing of physicians; 3) strengthen
            finance and management by system development and pilot
            testing rationalization strategies, accompanied by a pilot
            demonstration evaluation and roll-out. Civil works and the
            provision of goods and services are also financed.
